intro: Benthamistella nigricans, commonly known as the black-barked mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that primarily grows on the branches of eucalyptus trees in Australia. It has a distinctive appearance with dark, leathery foliage and a rough, blackish bark that gives it its common name. The plant produces small, white or pale green flowers followed by fleshy, red berries that are an important food source for native birds. It plays a role in the ecosystem by providing habitat and sustenance while also drawing nutrients from its host. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
